provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendant must create and retain certain records for 20 years after entry of the Order, retaining each such record for 5 years.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Commission Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission and Plaintiff are authorized to monitor Defendant's compliance through various means including inspections, interviews, and discovery.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: This Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and the Health Breach Notification Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 318

provisions.title: Mandated Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondents must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive information security program within 60 days of the Order's effective date, meeting detailed minimum requirements across documentation, risk assessment, safeguards, training, encryption, access controls, and data minimization.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Information Security Assessments by a Third Party
provisions.summary: Respondents must obtain initial and biennial independent third-party assessments of their Information Security Program, with the Assessor approved by the FTC, covering the first 180 days and each two-year period thereafter for 20 years, and submit reports to the Commission.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third-Party Information Security Assessor
provisions.summary: Respondents must fully cooperate with the third-party Assessor by providing all relevant information, network visibility, and disclosing all material facts without misrepresentation.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Respondents must annually provide the FTC with a certification from a senior corporate manager attesting to compliance with the Order, absence of uncorrected material noncompliance, and describing any Covered Incidents during the certified period.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Credit Monitoring and Identity Protection Product
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide Affected Consumers with enrollment in an FTC-approved credit monitoring and identity protection product for two years, including daily credit monitoring, dark web alerts, identity theft insurance, and accessible enrollment for incarcerated consumers.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Covered Incident Notification to Consumers and Facilities
provisions.summary: Following any future Covered Incident, Respondents must identify Future Affected Consumers and notify them and affected Facilities within 30 days of any government notification, including specific required information about the incident.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports to the Commission
provisions.summary: Within 10 days of notifying any government entity of a Covered Incident, Respondents must submit a detailed report to the FTC including the incident's date, description, affected information types, number of consumers, and remediation actions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Security and Privacy
provisions.summary: Respondents and their agents must not misrepresent their privacy and security measures, the occurrence or nature of any Covered Incident, notification efforts, industry-standard compliance, or their overall protection of Personal Information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Notification to Consumers Affected by the Identified Breach
provisions.summary: Within 120 days of Third Party approval, Respondents must post a required banner notice on all relevant websites and mobile apps for one year, and Telmate must send a direct notice to each Affected Consumer who did not receive written notice of the Identified Breach in May 2021.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Notification to Facilities
provisions.summary: Within 120 days of Third Party approval, Telmate must send a notice by certified mail or courier to all Facilities with a known relationship to incarcerated Affected Consumers, describing obligations and providing information necessary to facilitate consumers' access to the credit monitoring product.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of the Order to the FTC within 10 days, deliver copies to all key personnel and controlled businesses, and obtain signed acknowledgments within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit a sworn annual compliance report one year after issuance, notify the FTC within 14 days of changes to contact information or corporate structure, and notify the FTC within 14 days of any bankruptcy filing.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must create and retain for five years specified categories of records, including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, marketing materials, security representations, Assessment materials, law enforcement communications, and all compliance records.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC has broad authority to monitor Respondents' compliance, including requiring sworn reports and document production within 10 days of request, conducting interviews, and using undercover methods.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates and Duration
provisions.summary: The Order is effective upon publication on ftc.gov and terminates 20 years from issuance, or 20 years from the most recent date the FTC files a complaint alleging a violation, whichever is later, with specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Required Disclosures
provisions.summary: Defendant must provide clear, conspicuous, written pre-signing disclosures for Credit Agreements covering identity of creditor, APR, amount financed, finance charges, payment schedule, total payments, security interest information, and potential impact of UCC filings; Defendant must also comply with TILA and Regulation Z.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); the Truth in Lending Act (TILA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 1601–1666j; section 621(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA), 15 U.S.C. § 1681s(a); and the Duties of Furnishers of Information to Consumer Reporting Agencies Rule, 12 C.F.R. § 1022, subpart E

provisions.title: Ban on Sale or Disclosure of Browsing Information
provisions.summary: Respondents are prohibited from selling, licensing, or otherwise disclosing Browsing Information to Third Parties for Advertising Purposes, and from using Browsing Information for Advertising Purposes without Affirmative Express Consent.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Prohibited Misleading Representations
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent the purpose of their collection or use of Covered Information, the extent to which it is aggregated or anonymized, or the extent to which they collect, use, disclose, or maintain Covered Information or protect its privacy and security.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Notice to Users
provisions.summary: Within 28 days of the effective date, Respondents must post a notice on their websites, notify users within affected Avast Products, and send the FTC-mandated Exhibit A Notice by email to affected users.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Mandated Privacy Program
provisions.summary: Within 60 days of the effective date, each Respondent that collects, uses, discloses, or maintains Covered Information must establish and maintain a comprehensive privacy program, including documentation, board reporting, designated personnel, risk assessments, safeguards, training, and ongoing monitoring.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third Party Assessor
provisions.summary: Respondents must fully cooperate with third-party Assessors by providing all relevant information, disclosing network and IT asset details, and not misrepresenting any material facts.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Monetary Relief
provisions.summary: Respondents must pay $16,500,000 to the FTC within 9 days of the effective date of this Order by electronic fund transfer.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Respondents relinquish all rights to transferred assets, agree that Complaint facts will be taken as true in any enforcement litigation, and acknowledge how unspent funds will be handled and the consequences of default.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of the Order within 10 days, deliver copies to all relevant personnel, and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days of delivery.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Report and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit a sworn compliance report one year after issuance, file notices of material changes within 14 days, notify the FTC of any bankruptcy filings, and submit all materials via the specified channels.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC is authorized to monitor Respondents' compliance by requesting compliance reports and records, communicating directly with Respondents, interviewing personnel, and using other lawful investigative means.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: This Order is effective upon publication on the FTC's website and terminates 20 years from issuance, or 20 years from the most recent date the FTC files a complaint alleging a violation of this Order in federal court, whichever is later.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Security
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent in any way the extent to which it maintains and protects the privacy, confidentiality, security, or integrity of personal information collected from consumers online.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq

provisions.title: Comprehensive Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive written information security program with administrative, technical, and physical safeguards, including risk designation, risk assessment, safeguard implementation, and ongoing evaluation.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq

provisions.title: Third-Party Security Assessments
provisions.summary: Respondent must obtain biennial third-party security assessments from a qualified professional for twenty years, with the first assessment due within 180 days of service, and provide assessments and supporting materials to the FTC.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must maintain and make available to the FTC compliance-related documents, including advertisements and representations about data security for five years, and assessment-related materials for three years after each biennial assessment.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq

provisions.title: Order Distribution and Acknowledgment
provisions.summary: Respondent must deliver a copy of this order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, managers, and employees with managerial responsibilities related to the order's subject matter within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq

provisions.title: Compliance Notification of Corporate Changes
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the FTC at least 30 days prior to any corporate change that may affect compliance obligations, including dissolution, merger, sale, name or address change, or bankruptcy filing.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting to FTC
provisions.summary: Respondent must file an initial written compliance report with the FTC within 180 days after service of the order, and at such other times as the Commission may require.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq

provisions.title: Order Duration
provisions.summary: This order terminates on March 4, 2025, or twenty years from the most recent date the FTC files a complaint alleging a violation of the order, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq

provisions.title: Comprehensive Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive written information security program with administrative, technical, and physical safeguards reasonably designed to protect the security, confidentiality, and integrity of personal information collected from or about consumers.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Biennial Third-Party Security Assessments
provisions.summary: Respondent must obtain an initial and biennial third-party security assessments from a qualified, independent professional covering the first 180 days after service and each two-year period thereafter for 20 years; each assessment must certify the security program's effectiveness and be submitted to the FTC.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must maintain and make available to the FTC documents relating to compliance with this order, including for five years any documents contradicting compliance, and for three years after each biennial assessment all plans, reports, and materials relating to compliance with Paragraphs I and II.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgment and Delivery
provisions.summary: For ten years after service of the order, respondent must deliver a copy of the order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, managers, and supervisory employees; current personnel must receive it within 30 days of service, and future personnel within 30 days of assuming their role.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Notice of Corporate Changes
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the FTC at least 30 days prior to any corporate change that may affect compliance obligations under the order, including dissolution, sale, merger, bankruptcy filing, or name/address change.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file an initial written compliance report with the FTC within 180 days after service of the order, and at such other times as the FTC may require.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: The order terminates on March 7, 2026, or twenty years from the most recent date the FTC files a complaint alleging a violation of the order in federal court, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Privacy and Security
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent, in any manner, the extent to which they maintain and protect the privacy, confidentiality, or integrity of consumers' personal information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Comprehensive Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondents must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive written information security program with administrative, technical, and physical safeguards appropriate to their size, complexity, and the sensitivity of personal information they collect.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Third-Party Security Assessments
provisions.summary: Respondents must obtain initial and biennial independent third-party security assessments covering defined reporting periods, with each assessment certifying the sufficiency of the security program, prepared by a qualified professional and submitted to the FTC.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must maintain and make available to the FTC copies of all materials used to prepare assessments (for 3 years) and all other compliance-related documents including advertisements (for 5 years).
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Delivery and Acknowledgment
provisions.summary: Respondents must deliver a copy of this order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, managers, employees, agents, and representatives with relevant responsibilities, within specified timeframes.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Notification of Corporate Changes
provisions.summary: Respondents must notify the FTC at least 30 days prior to any corporate change that may affect compliance obligations under this order, including dissolutions, mergers, sales, bankruptcy filings, or name/address changes.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondents must file a written compliance report with the FTC within 180 days after service of the order, and at such other times as the Commission may require.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: The order terminates on March 16, 2029, or twenty years from the most recent date the U.S. or FTC files a federal court complaint alleging a violation of the order, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Security and Privacy
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent in any manner the extent to which it maintains and protects the security, privacy, confidentiality, or integrity of any nonpublic consumer information, including misrepresentations about preventing unauthorized access or honoring user privacy choices.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Comprehensive Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive written information security program with administrative, technical, and physical safeguards, including risk assessment, safeguard implementation, service provider oversight, and program evaluation.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Biennial Third-Party Security Assessments
provisions.summary: Respondent must obtain initial and biennial third-party security assessments from a qualified, independent professional covering the first 180 days after service and each two-year period thereafter for ten years, with each assessment setting forth safeguards, their appropriateness, compliance with Part II, and certifying program effectiveness.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must maintain and make available to the FTC copies of widely-disseminated security statements (3 years), consumer complaints (6 months), law enforcement communications (2 years), documents contradicting compliance (5 years), and materials used to prepare assessments (3 years after each assessment).
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Order Delivery and Acknowledgment
provisions.summary: Respondent must deliver a copy of this order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, managers, employees, agents, and representatives with relevant responsibilities within 30 days of service or assumption of responsibilities.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Compliance Notification of Corporate Changes
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the FTC at least 30 days prior to any corporate change that may affect compliance obligations, including dissolution, merger, sale, bankruptcy filing, or name/address change; if less than 30 days' notice is possible, notification must be made as soon as practicable.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file an initial written compliance report within 60 days of service of the order and submit additional written reports within 10 days of written notice from the Commission.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination

provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45 et seq.

provisions.title: Civil Penalty
provisions.summary: Defendant must pay a civil penalty of $250,000 to the United States within 5 days of receipt of notice of entry of the Order.

provisions.summary: Oracle must notify Affected Consumers that they may have older, insecure Iterations of Java SE on their computers, including via website hyperlink, security bulletins, social media, and by providing free uninstall tools and support.

provisions.summary: Defendant must permanently expire all RewardU-related cookies and notify all affected consumers to uninstall the toolbar and delete associated cookies within 30 days of entry of the Order.

provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendant must submit a sworn compliance report one year after entry of the Order, and for 20 years thereafter must submit sworn compliance notices within 14 days of certain changes in structure or contact information, and within 14 days of any bankruptcy filing.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Defendant must create certain records for 20 years after entry of the Order and retain each such record for 5 years, including compliance records, accounting records, and personnel records.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: Plaintiff and the FTC have broad rights to monitor Defendant's compliance, including demanding additional reports, conducting depositions and discovery, communicating directly with Defendant, and using undercover means, all without further court order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction of this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Disclosure and Consent for Targeting Tool
provisions.summary: Respondent must clearly and prominently disclose all types of data collected and how it is used, and must obtain express affirmative consent from consumers prior to enabling any Targeting Tool, including for previously installed TurboSaver Toolbars before making material changes.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Notification to Affected Consumers
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify Affected Consumers about the Personalized Offers feature, the data collected, and how to disable and uninstall the TurboSaver Toolbar through website posting, direct consumer inquiries, and direct notice.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Deletion of Collected Information
provisions.summary: Respondent must delete or destroy all Collected Information in its custody or control within 5 days of service of the FTC Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Privacy and Security
provisions.summary: Respondent must not make any false or misleading representations about the extent to which it maintains and protects the security, privacy, confidentiality, or integrity of personal information collected from consumers.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Comprehensive Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish and maintain a comprehensive, fully documented information security program with administrative, technical, and physical safeguards appropriate to its size, complexity, and the sensitivity of the personal information it collects.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Third-Party Security Assessments of Covered Online Services
provisions.summary: Respondent must obtain initial and biennial third-party security assessments for any Covered Online Service from a qualified, independent professional, covering the first 180 days and each two-year period thereafter for 20 years.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must maintain and make available for FTC inspection, for 5 years after the last dissemination of any covered representation, all advertisements, supporting materials, contradicting evidence, and Order acknowledgments; and for 3 years after each assessment, all materials used to prepare that assessment.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Cooperation with the Commission
provisions.summary: Respondent must cooperate in good faith with the FTC in connection with this action or any related subsequent investigation, appearing for interviews, conferences, discovery, and proceedings as reasonably requested.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Respondent must deliver a copy of the FTC Order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, and relevant managers, and obtain a signed and dated acknowledgment from each recipient.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting / Notification of Changes
provisions.summary: Respondent must notify the FTC at least 30 days prior to any change that may affect compliance obligations, including dissolution, sale, merger, creation or dissolution of subsidiaries, bankruptcy filing, or change in name or address.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondent must file a written compliance report within 60 days of service of the FTC Order and submit additional written reports within 10 days of the FTC's written request.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Order Duration / Termination
provisions.summary: The FTC Order terminates on December 31, 2031, or 20 years from the most recent date the United States or the FTC files a complaint alleging any violation of the order in federal court, whichever is later.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(l) and Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(l) and 56(a)(1)

provisions.title: Monitoring Products and Services
provisions.summary: Respondents are permanently restrained from promoting, selling, or distributing any Monitoring Product or Service unless they comply with requirements for mobile device security, registration attestation, documentation, and icon notice.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule)

provisions.title: Additional Warnings and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondents are permanently restrained from promoting, selling, or distributing Monitoring Products or Services unless they provide purchasers with required home page and purchase page notices about lawful use only.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule)

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning the Collection of Personal Information
provisions.summary: Respondents are permanently restrained from violating the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA), 16 C.F.R. Part 312, including failing to establish reasonable procedures to protect the confidentiality, security, and integrity of children's Personal Information.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Respondents are permanently restrained from misrepresenting, expressly or by implication, the extent to which they maintain and protect the privacy, security, confidentiality, or integrity of Personal Information.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule)

provisions.title: Mandated Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Each Covered Business must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive written information security program with specific components including risk assessments, safeguards, testing, and service provider oversight.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule)

provisions.title: Information Security Assessments by a Third Party
provisions.summary: Respondents must obtain initial and biennial third-party assessments of their Information Security Program from a qualified, independent assessor, covering the first 180 days and then every 2 years for 20 years.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule)

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third Party Information Security Assessor
provisions.summary: Respondents must cooperate fully with third-party Assessors by disclosing all material facts truthfully and providing all relevant information and materials in their possession.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule)

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide the FTC with an annual certification from a senior corporate manager or officer confirming compliance with the Information Security Program requirements and disclosing any Covered Incidents.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule)

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit a report to the FTC within 10 days of first notifying any government entity of a Covered Incident, including details about the incident's date, description, affected information types, consumer count, remediation steps, and copies of notices sent.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule)

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of this Order within 7 days, deliver copies of the Order to principals, officers, managers, and relevant employees for 10 years, and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule)

provisions.title: Compliance Report and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit a sworn compliance report one year after entry of this Order and provide sworn compliance notices within 14 days of any changes in contact information, business structure, or individual respondent's personal or business circumstances for 10 years.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must create certain records for 10 years after entry of this Order and retain each such record for 5 years, including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, assessment materials, compliance records, and marketing materials.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC is authorized to monitor Respondents' compliance through written requests for reports and documents, depositions, direct communications with employees, and other lawful investigative means including undercover contacts.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule)

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: This Order is final and effective upon publication on the FTC website and terminates on March 26, 2040, or 20 years from the most recent date the United States or Commission files a complaint alleging any violation of this Order, whichever is later.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Participation in or Compliance with Privacy Programs
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent, in any manner, the extent to which it participates in, complies with, or is certified under any privacy or security program sponsored by a government or self-regulatory organization, including EU-U.S. Privacy Shield, Swiss-U.S. Privacy Shield, and APEC Cross-Border Privacy Rules.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit an acknowledgment of receipt of the Order to the Commission within ten days, deliver copies of the Order to relevant personnel within specified timeframes, and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within thirty days of delivery.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Report and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit an initial sworn compliance report within 60 days, submit sworn notices of changes to contact information or corporate structure within 14 days, and submit notice of any bankruptcy filing within 14 days, all in accordance with specified submission requirements.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must create specified records for ten years after the Order's issuance date and retain each record for five years, including accounting records, personnel records, compliance records, and copies of representations subject to the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission is authorized to monitor Respondent's compliance through written requests for reports and records, direct communications and interviews with affiliated persons, and other lawful investigative means including undercover inquiries.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: The Order is final and effective upon publication on the FTC's website and terminates on March 16, 2040, or twenty years from the most recent date a complaint alleging a violation is filed in federal court, whichever is later, with specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Mandated Automated Biometric Security or Surveillance System Monitoring Program
provisions.summary: Before using any biometric surveillance system, Respondents must establish a comprehensive monitoring program to assess and mitigate risks of harm to consumers, including discriminatory impacts.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5(a) and 5(n) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n)

provisions.title: Mandatory Notice and Complaint Procedures for Automated Biometric Security or Surveillance Systems
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide written notice to consumers enrolled in biometric galleries or affected by system outputs, and establish complaint procedures with required response times.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5(a) and 5(n) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n)

provisions.title: Disclosure of Automated Biometric Security or Surveillance Systems
provisions.summary: Respondents must post Clear and Conspicuous notices disclosing use of biometric surveillance systems in all locations where they are deployed.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5(a) and 5(n) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent their privacy, security, or data practices related to Covered Information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5(a) and 5(n) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n)

provisions.title: Mandated Information Security Program for Covered Businesses
provisions.summary: Respondents must establish and maintain a comprehensive information security program with specific technical, administrative, and vendor management safeguards.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5(a) and 5(n) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n)

provisions.title: Third Party Information Security Assessments for Covered Businesses
provisions.summary: Respondents must obtain initial and biennial third-party assessments of their Information Security Program for 20 years.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5(a) and 5(n) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n)

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third-Party Information Security Assessor
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide all relevant information to the third-party Assessor and not misrepresent any material facts.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5(a) and 5(n) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n)

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide annual certifications from the CEO or senior officer confirming compliance with the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5(a) and 5(n) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n)

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Respondents must report to the FTC any Covered Incidents affecting 500 or more consumers within 10 days of notifying government entities.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5(a) and 5(n) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n)

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondents must obtain signed acknowledgments of the Order from all relevant personnel and entities for 20 years.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5(a) and 5(n) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n)

provisions.title: Compliance Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit annual compliance reports and timely notices of any structural changes or bankruptcy proceedings.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5(a) and 5(n) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must create and retain records for 20 years documenting compliance with all provisions of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5(a) and 5(n) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC has authority to monitor compliance through requests for reports, depositions, document production, and interviews.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5(a) and 5(n) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n)

provisions.title: Modification of Original Decision and Order
provisions.summary: This Order supersedes the 2010 Decision and Order previously issued against Rite Aid.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5(a) and 5(n) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n)

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: The Order is effective upon publication on ftc.gov and terminates 20 years from issuance or from the most recent complaint filing, whichever is later.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5(a) and 5(n) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), (n)

provisions.title: Mandated Automated Biometric Security or Surveillance System Monitoring Program
provisions.summary: Before using any Automated Biometric Security or Surveillance System, Respondents must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive monitoring Program that identifies and addresses consumer risks, including disproportionate impacts by race, ethnicity, gender, sex, age, or disability.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Mandatory Notice and Complaint Procedures for Automated Biometric Security or Surveillance Systems
provisions.summary: Before using any Automated Biometric Security or Surveillance System, Respondents must establish and maintain procedures providing consumers with notice of Gallery enrollment and Output-based actions, and a process for submitting and responding to complaints.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Required Retention Limits for Biometric Information
provisions.summary: Before implementing any Automated Biometric Security or Surveillance System, Respondents must develop and implement a written retention schedule for each type of consumer Biometric Information, setting out purposes, a deletion timeframe of no greater than five years, and the basis for that timeframe.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Disclosure of Automated Biometric Security or Surveillance Systems
provisions.summary: Within 30 days of the effective date, Respondents must post Clear and Conspicuous notices in each retail location and on each website/app/online service disclosing their use of Automated Biometric Security or Surveillance Systems, including types of biometric data collected, outputs generated, purposes, and deletion timeframes.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent in any manner the extent to which they maintain and protect the privacy, security, confidentiality, or integrity of Covered Information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Mandated Information Security Program for Covered Businesses
provisions.summary: Within 90 days of the effective date, Respondents must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive Information Security Program protecting the security, confidentiality, and integrity of Covered Information, including extensive safeguards, vendor management, and ongoing risk assessments.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Third Party Information Security Assessments for Covered Businesses
provisions.summary: Respondents must obtain initial and biennial independent third-party assessments of their Information Security Program, covering the first 180 days after the Program is established and every two years thereafter for 20 years.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third-Party Information Security Assessor
provisions.summary: Respondents must fully cooperate with the Assessor by providing all relevant information, disclosing network and IT asset details, and not misrepresenting any material facts to the Assessor.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: One year after issuance, and each year thereafter, Respondents must provide the FTC with a sworn certification from a senior executive confirming compliance with the Order, absence of uncorrected/undisclosed material noncompliance, and a description of all qualifying Covered Incidents during the certified period.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Within 10 days of notifying any U.S. government entity of a Covered Incident affecting 500 or more consumers, Respondents must submit a detailed report to the FTC.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit acknowledgment of receipt of the Order within 10 days, deliver copies to all principals, officers, directors, subsidiaries, and relevant employees, and obtain signed acknowledgments within 30 days of delivery.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Compliance Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit annual compliance reports, compliance notices within 14 days of changes in contact information or corporate structure, and bankruptcy filing notices within 14 days of filing.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must create certain records for 20 years after issuance and retain each for five years, including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, compliance records, System Assessment materials, security representations, Assessor materials, law enforcement subpoenas, and noncompliance records.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC is authorized to monitor Respondents' compliance through requests for reports and records, depositions, discovery, direct communications, interviews, and undercover methods, with Respondents obligated to respond within 14 days of written requests.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Modification of Original Decision and Order
provisions.summary: This Decision and Order supersedes and replaces the Commission's 2010 Decision and Order in In re Rite Aid Corporation, C-4308.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates and Duration
provisions.summary: The Order is effective upon publication on the FTC's website and terminates 20 years from issuance or 20 years from the most recent federal court complaint alleging a violation, whichever is later, with specified exceptions for individual provisions, non-defendant respondents, and dismissed complaints.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Injunction Against COPPA Rule Violations
provisions.summary: Defendants and all persons acting in concert with them are permanently enjoined from violating any provision of the COPPA Rule, as currently promulgated or as modified in the future.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Children's Privacy
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from making any misrepresentation in a website's privacy policy or elsewhere about the collection, use, or disclosure of children's personal information, or about procedures to maintain its confidentiality, security, or integrity.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Civil Penalty — $35,000
provisions.summary: Defendants Bigmailbox.com, Inc. and Nolan Quan are jointly and severally required to pay a civil penalty of $35,000 to the United States.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Payment of Civil Penalty — Method and Delivery
provisions.summary: Defendants must pay the $35,000 civil penalty on the date of entry of the Consent Decree by certified or cashier's check payable to the Treasurer of the United States.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Default Interest on Civil Penalty
provisions.summary: If defendants default on payment for more than ten days past the due date, the entire unpaid penalty plus interest becomes immediately due and payable.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Distribution of Consent Decree and Compliance Guide to Current Personnel
provisions.summary: Within 30 days of entry, defendants must provide a copy of the Consent Decree and FTC compliance guide to all current principals, officers, directors, managers, and relevant employees, obtain signed acknowledgment statements, and within 10 days thereafter submit a signed compliance statement to the FTC.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Distribution of Consent Decree and Compliance Guide to Future Personnel
provisions.summary: Defendants must provide a copy of the Consent Decree and compliance guide to all future principals, officers, directors, managers, and relevant employees within 30 days of their assuming such position, and maintain copies of signed acknowledgment statements available to the FTC upon request.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Initial Compliance Report
provisions.summary: Within 60 days of entry, defendants must file a written compliance report with the FTC detailing their compliance with the Consent Decree, including registration processes, privacy notices, parental consent methods, and data security procedures.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping — Compliance Documents
provisions.summary: For five years, defendants must maintain and make available to the FTC within seven days of request print or electronic copies of all documents demonstrating compliance with the Consent Decree, including every information collection form, web page, and representation about data practices.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Notification of Business Changes — Bigmailbox.com, Inc.
provisions.summary: Defendants must notify the FTC at least 30 days prior to any corporate change affecting compliance obligations, such as mergers, dissolutions, bankruptcies, or name/address changes.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Taxpayer Identification Numbers
provisions.summary: Defendants are required to furnish their taxpayer identifying numbers to the FTC for use in collecting and reporting on any delinquent amounts arising from their government relationship.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Submission Address for Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: All reports, submissions, and notices required by Paragraphs 12–19 must be sent by certified mail to the FTC's Associate Director, Division of Advertising Practices.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Continuing Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter to enable any party to seek further orders for interpretation, modification, enforcement of compliance, or punishment of violations.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting — Initial Written Report
provisions.summary: Within sixty days of entry, defendant must file a detailed written compliance report with the Commission covering privacy notices, parental consent procedures, data collection practices, and security measures for all Rule-covered websites.

provisions.title: Injunction Against COPPA Rule Violations
provisions.summary: Defendants and all persons acting in concert with them are permanently enjoined from violating any provision of the COPPA Rule, as currently promulgated or as amended in the future.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Civil Penalty — $30,000 Payment
provisions.summary: Defendants Monarch Services, Inc. and Girls' Life, Inc. must jointly and severally pay a civil penalty of $30,000 to the United States.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Civil Penalty — Payment Mechanics
provisions.summary: Defendants must pay the $30,000 civil penalty on the date of entry of the Consent Decree by certified or cashier's check payable to the Treasurer of the United States and delivered to the Office of Consumer Litigation.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Default in Civil Penalty Payment
provisions.summary: If defendants default on payment for more than ten days beyond the due date, the entire unpaid penalty plus interest becomes immediately due and payable.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Acknowledgment — Current Personnel
provisions.summary: Defendants must provide copies of the Consent Decree and COPPA compliance guide to all current principals, officers, directors, managers, and relevant employees, obtain signed acknowledgments from each, and submit a compliance statement to the FTC within ten days.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting

provisions.summary: Respondents must not violate any provision of the GLB Act's Safeguards Rule (16 C.F.R. Part 314) or Privacy Rule (16 C.F.R. Part 313), directly or through any corporate entity or device.

provisions.summary: Respondents must obtain biennial independent third-party security assessments certifying their information security program, and provide the first assessment and related materials to the FTC within 10 days of preparation.

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgment and Delivery
provisions.summary: Respondents must deliver a copy of this order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, managers, employees, agents, and representatives with relevant responsibilities — current personnel within 30 days of service, future personnel within 30 days of assuming their role.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1), and Title V of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. § 6801 et seq.

provisions.summary: Respondent John D. Eubank must notify the FTC for 10 years of any discontinuance of current business or employment, or any affiliation with new business or employment, including new address, phone number, and description of duties.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1), and Title V of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. § 6801 et seq.

provisions.title: Corporate Change Notification
provisions.summary: Respondents must notify the FTC at least 30 days before any corporate change (dissolution, merger, sale, name change, bankruptcy filing, etc.) that may affect compliance obligations under this order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1), and Title V of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. § 6801 et seq.

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondents must file a written compliance report with the FTC within 180 days of service of the order, and at such other times as the FTC may require, including a copy of the initial Assessment from Part II.

provisions.title: Order Duration and Termination
provisions.summary: This order terminates on April 12, 2025, or 20 years from the most recent date the FTC or United States files a federal court complaint alleging a violation of the order, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1), and Title V of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, 15 U.S.C. § 6801 et seq.

provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent in any manner, expressly or by implication, the extent to which it maintains and protects the privacy, confidentiality, security, or integrity of personal information collected from consumers.

provisions.title: Comprehensive Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondent must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive information security program, fully documented in writing, with administrative, technical, and physical safeguards appropriate to the sensitivity of personal information collected.

provisions.title: Third-Party Security Assessments
provisions.summary: Respondent must obtain initial and biennial third-party security assessments from a qualified, independent professional covering the first 180 days after service of the order and each two-year period thereafter for ten years.
