provisions.summary: The Order is effective upon publication on the FTC website and terminates on September 3, 2039, or 20 years from the most recent date the Commission files a complaint alleging a violation of this Order, whichever is later.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)(1), and the Standards for Safeguarding Customer Information Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent, expressly or by implication, its security or privacy practices, how it handles Personal Information or Health Information, its membership in any privacy/security programs, or any government approvals of its products or services.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Affirmative Express Consent for Disclosure of Health Information to Third Parties
provisions.summary: Respondent must not disclose any Health Information to any Third Party unless it first obtains the Affirmative Express Consent of the individual identifiable by that Health Information, except as required by law.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Destruction of Saliva Samples
provisions.summary: Within 30 days of the Order's issuance, Respondent must instruct laboratories to destroy retained physical DNA saliva samples held more than 180 days after Respondent accepted analysis results, and must provide sworn written confirmation of those instructions to the Commission.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Mandated Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Within 60 days of the Order's issuance, Respondent must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive information security program protecting the security, confidentiality, and integrity of Personal Information, with specific minimum requirements including documentation, risk assessment, safeguards, testing, and service provider oversight.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Information Security Assessments by a Third Party
provisions.summary: Respondent must obtain initial and biennial independent third-party assessments of its Information Security Program, covering the first 180 days after the Order and each two-year period thereafter for 20 years, with assessments completed within 60 days after each reporting period and submitted to the Commission.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third-Party Information Security Assessor
provisions.summary: Respondent must fully cooperate with the third-party Assessor by providing all relevant information, network and IT asset access, and disclosing all material facts without misrepresentation.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Beginning one year after the Order's issuance and annually thereafter, Respondent must provide the Commission with a certification from a senior corporate manager or officer attesting to compliance with the Order, absence of uncorrected or undisclosed material noncompliance, and describing all Covered Incidents during the certified period.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit a report to the Commission within 10 days of notifying any government entity of a Covered Incident, or within 10 business days of discovering unauthorized access to individually identifiable Health Information, including specified details about the incident.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Monetary Relief
provisions.summary: Respondent must pay $75,000 to the Commission within 8 days of the Order's effective date by electronic fund transfer.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Respondent relinquishes all rights to transferred assets, agrees that Complaint facts may be taken as true in subsequent enforcement proceedings, and acknowledges the Commission's authority to use paid funds for consumer redress or related relief, with interest accruing on any default.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Customer Information
provisions.summary: Respondent must provide sufficient customer information to enable the Commission to administer consumer redress to all Covered Customers, and must supply any additional redress-related information requested by the Commission within 14 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of this Order within 10 days, deliver copies to all relevant personnel within 10 days (and before new personnel assume responsibilities), and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days of delivery.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit an initial compliance report on saliva sample destruction within 90 days, a comprehensive annual compliance report one year after issuance, compliance notices within 14 days of specified changes, and notice of any bankruptcy filing within 14 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must create and retain specified records for 20 years after the Order's issuance (retaining each for at least 5 years), including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, privacy/security representations, consent documents, Assessment materials, and all compliance records.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission is authorized to monitor Respondent's compliance by requesting additional reports, records, and interviews, and may use other lawful means including posing as consumers or suppliers without prior notice.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: The Order is final and effective upon publication on the FTC's website and terminates 20 years from its issuance date, or 20 years from the most recent date the Commission files a complaint alleging any violation of the Order, whichever is later.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Prevention of CSAM and NCM
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently restrained from misrepresenting the extent to which they review, remove, prevent, or protect consumers from CSAM and NCM on their Covered Services.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.title: Mandated Suspension of Content
provisions.summary: Defendants must suspend all pre-program Model-uploaded content where age verification or consent has not been confirmed, and all pre-program Content Partner content not meeting required safeguards, within specified timeframes.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.title: Mandated Program to Prevent the Posting and Proliferation of CSAM and NCM
provisions.summary: Defendants must establish and implement a comprehensive CSAM and NCM Prevention Program within 90 days, including documentation, governance, risk assessment, safeguards (age/consent verification, content review, removal processes), training, reporting tools, and biannual transparency reports.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.title: CSAM and NCM Prevention Program Assessments by a Third Party
provisions.summary: Defendants must obtain initial and biennial independent third-party assessments of their CSAM and NCM Prevention Program, with specific assessor qualifications, reporting periods, assessment content requirements, and submission deadlines.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third-Party CSAM and NCM Prevention Assessor
provisions.summary: Defendants must cooperate fully with the CSAM and NCM Prevention Assessor by providing all relevant information, access to content management systems, and accurate disclosures without misrepresentation.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.title: Annual Certifications – CSAM and NCM Prevention
provisions.summary: Defendants must annually provide the FTC and the Division with a CEO certification attesting to compliance with Provisions I–V and disclosure of any uncorrected material noncompliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.title: Notice to Users
provisions.summary: Defendants must post the court-mandated consumer notice (Exhibit A) prominently on all Covered Service landing pages within 14 days of Order entry and maintain it for 2 years.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Privacy or Information Security
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently restrained from misrepresenting how they collect, maintain, use, disclose, or protect Covered Information, or the control individuals have over their information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.title: Mandated Privacy and Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Defendants must establish a comprehensive Privacy and Information Security Program within 60 days, including documentation, governance, risk assessment, safeguards (access controls, encryption, data retention, training), and ongoing monitoring and evaluation.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.title: Privacy and Information Security Assessments by a Third Party
provisions.summary: Defendants must obtain initial and biennial independent third-party assessments of their Privacy and Information Security Program, with specific assessor qualifications, reporting periods, assessment content requirements, and submission deadlines.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third-Party Privacy and Information Security Assessor
provisions.summary: Defendants must cooperate fully with the Privacy and Security Assessor by providing all relevant information, network/IT asset visibility, and accurate disclosures without misrepresentation.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.title: Annual Certifications – Privacy and Information Security
provisions.summary: Defendants must annually provide the FTC and the Division with a senior officer certification attesting to compliance with the Order's requirements, no uncorrected noncompliance, and a description of all Covered Incidents during the certified period.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Within 10 days of notifying any U.S. government entity of a Covered Incident, Defendants must submit a detailed report to the Commission and the Division describing the incident, affected information, consumer impact, remediation steps, and notices sent.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment
provisions.summary: A $15 million civil penalty judgment is entered in favor of the Utah Division; $5 million is due within 7 days of Order entry; the remaining $10 million is suspended conditional on compliance and may be reinstated upon contempt finding.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Defendants relinquish all rights to assets transferred under the Order; Complaint facts are taken as true in future enforcement proceedings; bankruptcy nondischargeability elements are established; Defendants must provide Tax Identification Numbers.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Each Defendant must acknowledge receipt of the Order under penalty of perjury within 7 days, deliver copies to principals, officers, and relevant employees within specified timeframes, and obtain signed acknowledgments within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit a sworn compliance report one year after Order entry, sworn compliance notices within 14 days of any structural or contact changes for 10 years, and bankruptcy filing notices within 14 days, using specified submission procedures.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission and Division are authorized to monitor Defendants' compliance through requests for reports and documents, depositions, direct communications, interviews, undercover monitoring, and all lawful compulsory process; Defendants may not take actions to evade the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Utah Consumer Sales Practices Act, Utah Code § 13-11-1 et seq.

provisions.title: Civil Penalty — $30,000 Payment
provisions.summary: Defendant must pay a $30,000 civil penalty by certified or cashier's check on the date of entry of the Consent Decree; default triggers accrual of interest on the unpaid balance.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, §§ 6502(c), 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58

provisions.title: Initial Distribution of Consent Decree and Compliance Guide (Current Personnel)
provisions.summary: Within thirty days of entry, defendant must provide copies of the Consent Decree and FTC compliance guide to all current principals, officers, directors, managers, and relevant employees/agents, obtain signed acknowledgments, and submit a compliance statement to the Commission within ten days thereafter.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, §§ 6502(c), 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58

provisions.title: Ongoing Distribution of Consent Decree and Compliance Guide (Future Personnel)
provisions.summary: For three years after entry, defendant must provide copies of the Consent Decree and compliance guide to future principals, officers, directors, managers, and relevant employees/agents within thirty days of them assuming their position, obtain signed acknowledgments, and retain those records.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, §§ 6502(c), 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting to the Commission
provisions.summary: Within 120 days of entry and at such other times as the FTC requires, defendant must file a detailed written compliance report covering privacy notices, parental consent procedures, information collection practices, and data security procedures.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, §§ 6502(c), 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: For five years after entry, defendant must maintain and make available to the FTC within fifteen days of request print or electronic copies (in HTML format) of all documents demonstrating compliance, including information collection forms, web pages, and representations about data practices.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, §§ 6502(c), 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58

provisions.title: Notice of Business Changes
provisions.summary: Defendant must notify the FTC at least thirty days before any business change that may affect compliance obligations under the Consent Decree, including mergers, dissolutions, bankruptcy filings, and name or address changes.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, §§ 6502(c), 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58

provisions.title: Taxpayer Identifying Number Disclosure
provisions.summary: Defendant must furnish its taxpayer identifying number to the FTC in accordance with 31 U.S.C. § 7701 for purposes of collecting and reporting on any delinquent amounts.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, §§ 6502(c), 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58

provisions.title: Address for Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: All reports, submissions, and notices required by Paragraphs 13–18 must be sent by certified mail to the Associate Director, Division of Advertising Practices, Bureau of Consumer Protection, FTC.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, §§ 6502(c), 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58

provisions.title: Continuing Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter to issue further orders for interpretation, modification, enforcement of compliance, or punishment of violations.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, §§ 6502(c), 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Security Products
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent, in connection with any security software product or service, either the extent to which the product reduces unauthorized access risk, or the extent to which it maintains, protects, or provides security or privacy features.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Performance of Security/Privacy Software
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent the performance, benefits, or efficacy of any computer software product or service marketed as enhancing the security or privacy of any computer or similar system.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Consumer Refund Program
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide refunds to current InternetALERT subscribers by sending a refund notification email, posting a refund notice on their website, and issuing refund payments within seven days of receiving a request.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Distribution of Order to Retailers and Affiliates
provisions.summary: Respondents must send a copy of this order by email to any retailer, affiliate, or other third party that advertises, promotes, offers for sale, sells, or distributes InternetALERT under an agreement with respondents.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must retain, for five years after the last dissemination of any covered representation, all advertisements, materials relied upon, and any tests or evidence that contradict or qualify the representation, and make them available to the FTC upon request.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Distribution to Personnel
provisions.summary: Respondents must deliver a copy of this order to all current and future principals, officers, directors, managers, employees, agents, and representatives with relevant responsibilities — current personnel within 30 days of service, future personnel within 30 days of assuming their role.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Corporate Change Notification — Bonzi Software, Inc.
provisions.summary: Bonzi Software, Inc. must notify the FTC at least 30 days prior to any corporate change that may affect compliance obligations, including dissolution, merger, sale, bankruptcy filing, or name/address change, by certified mail to the FTC's Associate Director of Enforcement.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Individual Respondents' Employment Change Notification
provisions.summary: Joe Bonzi and Jay Bonzi must, for 10 years after entry of this order, notify the FTC of any discontinuance of their current business or employment and any affiliation with a new business or employment, by certified mail to the FTC's Associate Director of Enforcement.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Respondents must file a written compliance report with the FTC within 120 days of service of this order, and at such other times as the FTC requires, detailing compliance with the order including a full description of the consumer redress program conducted under Part III.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Duration
provisions.summary: This order terminates on October 7, 2024, or 20 years from the most recent date a complaint alleging a violation of the order is filed in federal court by the U.S. or FTC, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: The Order is effective upon publication on the FTC's website and terminates on October 25, 2038, or 20 years from the most recent date the FTC files a complaint alleging any violation of the Order in federal court, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Permanent Injunction — Continuation
provisions.summary: The original Permanent Injunction remains in full force and effect, except that Sections VI through IX are replaced by Sections V through VIII of this Amended Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment and Consumer Redress
provisions.summary: A judgment of $100,000,000 is entered against LifeLock; LifeLock must deposit the full amount into the Court's Registry within five business days and satisfy all related obligations governing disbursement, crediting, and remittance to the Commission.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Customer Information
provisions.summary: LifeLock must provide customer information requested by the Commission to facilitate consumer redress, including responding to written requests within 10 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Entry of Order
provisions.summary: The court finds no just reason for delay and directs the clerk to enter the Order immediately.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: For five years, LifeLock must notify the Commission of corporate changes at least 30 days in advance, file annual sworn compliance reports, and notify the Commission of any bankruptcy filings within 15 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission is authorized to monitor LifeLock's compliance through written reports, document production, depositions, site inspections, undercover investigations, and employee interviews, using all lawful means including civil discovery.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Record Keeping Provisions
provisions.summary: LifeLock must create and retain specified categories of records for defined periods: 13 years from the Permanent Injunction for business and compliance records, 3 years for biennial assessment materials, and 5 years from this Order for consumer redress payment records.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Distribution of Order
provisions.summary: For five years, LifeLock must deliver copies of the Permanent Injunction and this Order to principals, officers, relevant employees, agents, and successor entities, and obtain signed acknowledgments of receipt within 30 days of delivery.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Acknowledgement of Receipt of This Order
provisions.summary: LifeLock must submit a sworn statement to the Commission acknowledging receipt of this Order within five business days of receiving it.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for all purposes.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Participation in or Compliance with Privacy Programs
provisions.summary: Respondent must not misrepresent in any manner its membership in, adherence to, compliance with, or participation in any government- or self-regulatory-sponsored privacy or security program, including the EU-U.S. Privacy Shield, Swiss-U.S. Privacy Shield, and APEC Cross-Border Privacy Rules.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit an acknowledgment of receipt to the Commission within 10 days, deliver copies of the Order to relevant personnel and any successor entities (within 10 days for current personnel, before assuming responsibilities for others), and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Report and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondent must file a sworn initial compliance report within 60 days, submit sworn notices within 14 days of structural or contact changes or bankruptcy filings, ensure all sworn submissions comply with 28 U.S.C. § 1746, and route all submissions to the FTC via the specified email or overnight courier.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must create specified records for 10 years and retain each for 5 years, including accounting records, personnel records, full compliance records, and copies of all representations subject to the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC may monitor compliance by requiring sworn reports and records within 10 days of a written request, communicating directly with and interviewing Respondent's personnel, and using all other lawful means including undercover contacts.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: The Order becomes final and effective 60 days after service and terminates on October 28, 2040, or 20 years from the most recent date the Commission files a complaint alleging a violation, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Privacy and Security
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent in any manner their collection, maintenance, use, deletion, or disclosure of Personal Information, or the extent to which they protect the privacy, security, availability, confidentiality, or integrity of Personal Information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Mandated Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Respondents must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive information security program within 180 days of the effective date, encompassing risk assessments, safeguards, training, incident response, access controls, encryption, vulnerability management, vendor oversight, and franchisee requirements.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Information Security Assessments by a Third Party
provisions.summary: Respondents must obtain initial and biennial third-party assessments of their Information Security Program from a qualified, independent assessor, covering the first 365 days and each 2-year period thereafter for 20 years, and submit assessments to the FTC.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third-Party Information Security Assessor
provisions.summary: Respondents must fully cooperate with the Third-Party Assessor by providing all relevant information, disclosing all material facts, and not misrepresenting any fact material to the assessment.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide an annual CEO certification to the FTC confirming compliance with the Order and disclosing any uncorrected material noncompliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Within 10 days of notifying any U.S. government entity of a Covered Incident, Respondents must submit a detailed report to the FTC including incident dates, causes, types of information affected, number of consumers impacted, remediation steps taken, and copies of notices sent.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Loyalty Rewards Program Accounts Review
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide U.S. consumers a clear and conspicuous method to request review of their Loyalty Rewards Program account for unauthorized activity within the preceding 12 months, and restore points lost to unauthorized third-party activity.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of the Order to the FTC within 10 days, deliver copies to all relevant officers, directors, employees, and agents, and obtain signed acknowledgments within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit a sworn compliance report one year after issuance, provide compliance notices within 14 days of any designated contact or structural changes, notify the Commission of any bankruptcy filings within 14 days, and submit all filings via email or overnight courier.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC has the authority to monitor Respondents' compliance by requesting additional reports and records within 10 days, communicating directly with and interviewing Respondents' affiliates, and using all other lawful means including undercover methods.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: The Order is effective upon publication on the FTC's website and terminates 20 years from its issuance date, or 20 years from the most recent federal court complaint alleging a violation, whichever is later, subject to specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Mandated Automated Biometric Security or Surveillance System Monitoring Program
provisions.summary: Before using any Automated Biometric Security or Surveillance System (other than prohibited facial recognition), Respondents must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive Monitoring Program to identify and address consumer risks, including risks of disproportionate harm based on race, ethnicity, gender, sex, age, or disability.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Mandatory Notice and Complaint Procedures for Automated Biometric Security or Surveillance Systems
provisions.summary: Before using any Automated Biometric Security or Surveillance System, Respondents must establish and maintain procedures to provide consumers with notice of Gallery enrollment and of adverse actions taken based on Outputs, and must investigate and respond to consumer complaints within specified timeframes.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Required Retention Limits for Biometric Information
provisions.summary: Prior to implementing any Automated Biometric Security or Surveillance System, Respondents must develop and implement a written retention schedule for each type of consumer Biometric Information collected, specifying purposes, a deletion timeframe of no more than five years, and the basis for that timeframe.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Disclosure of Automated Biometric Security or Surveillance Systems
provisions.summary: Within 30 days of the effective date, Respondents must post Clear and Conspicuous notices in each physical retail location and on each website, mobile application, or online service disclosing the use of any Automated Biometric Security or Surveillance System, including types of Biometric Information collected, types of Outputs generated, purposes for use, and retention timeframes.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Respondents must not misrepresent in any manner the extent to which they maintain and protect the privacy, security, confidentiality, or integrity of Covered Information, including misrepresentations about security measures, privacy choices, data collection/use/deletion practices, or third-party access.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Mandated Information Security Program for Covered Businesses
provisions.summary: Within 90 days of the effective date, Respondents must establish, implement, and maintain a comprehensive Information Security Program protecting the security, confidentiality, and integrity of Covered Information, encompassing documentation, board reporting, designated leadership, risk assessments, safeguards, vendor management, and ongoing evaluation.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Third Party Information Security Assessments for Covered Businesses
provisions.summary: Respondents must obtain initial and biennial independent third-party assessments of the Information Security Program from a qualified Assessor approved by the FTC, covering the first 180 days after the Program is established and each two-year period thereafter for 20 years, with detailed assessment requirements and submission obligations.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Cooperation with Third-Party Information Security Assessor
provisions.summary: Respondents must fully cooperate with the third-party Assessor by providing all relevant information, network and IT asset access, and disclosing all material facts without misrepresentation.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Annual Certification
provisions.summary: Respondents must provide annual certifications from their CEO (or designated senior officer) confirming compliance with the Order, absence of uncorrected material noncompliance, and describing all Covered Incidents affecting 100 or more consumers during the certified period.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Covered Incident Reports
provisions.summary: Within 10 days of notifying any U.S. government entity of a Covered Incident affecting 500 or more consumers, Respondents must submit a report to the Commission detailing the incident's date, facts, affected information types, number of affected consumers, remediation actions taken, and copies of consumer notices.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit their own acknowledgment of receipt within 10 days, deliver copies of the Order to current and future principals, officers, relevant employees, subsidiaries, and agents for 20 years, and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondents must submit an initial sworn compliance report one year after issuance, provide sworn notices within 14 days of structural or contact changes or bankruptcy filings, and submit all required documents to the Commission via specified channels.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondents must create certain records for 20 years after the issuance date and retain each for five years (unless otherwise specified), including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, compliance records, System Assessment materials, privacy/security representations, Assessor materials, law enforcement communications, and records of non-compliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission is authorized to monitor Respondents' compliance by requesting additional reports, conducting depositions, obtaining records, communicating directly with Respondents, interviewing affiliated individuals, and using all other lawful means including undercover operations.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Modification of Original Decision and Order
provisions.summary: This Decision and Order supersedes the Commission's prior 2010 Decision and Order in In re Rite Aid Corporation, C-4308.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates
provisions.summary: This Order is final and effective upon publication on ftc.gov and will terminate 20 years from the date of issuance, or 20 years from the most recent date the United States or Commission files a federal court complaint alleging a violation of this Order, whichever is later, with specified exceptions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Civil Penalty
provisions.summary: PLS and PLS-Illinois must pay a civil penalty of $101,500 to the U.S. Treasury for violations of the FCRA.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), 53(b), and 56(a); Section 621(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681s(a); Disposal Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 682; Safeguards Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314; Privacy Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 313

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations About Security
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently prohibited from making false or misleading representations about the extent to which they protect the security, privacy, confidentiality, or integrity of personal information collected from consumers.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), 53(b), and 56(a); Section 621(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681s(a); Disposal Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 682; Safeguards Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314; Privacy Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 313

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Violating FCRA Disposal Rule
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently prohibited from violating the FCRA Disposal Rule, including failing to properly dispose of consumer information by taking reasonable measures to protect against unauthorized access.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), 53(b), and 56(a); Section 621(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681s(a); Disposal Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 682; Safeguards Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314; Privacy Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 313

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Violating GLB Safeguards Rule
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently prohibited from violating the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act Safeguards Rule, including failing to develop, implement, or maintain a comprehensive written information security program.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), 53(b), and 56(a); Section 621(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681s(a); Disposal Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 682; Safeguards Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314; Privacy Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 313

provisions.title: Required Information Security Program
provisions.summary: Defendants must establish and maintain a comprehensive written information security program designed to protect the security, confidentiality, and integrity of personal information collected from consumers.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), 53(b), and 56(a); Section 621(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681s(a); Disposal Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 682; Safeguards Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314; Privacy Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 313

provisions.title: Third-Party Security Assessments
provisions.summary: Defendants must obtain initial and biennial third-party security assessments from qualified professionals for 20 years, certifying that their security program provides reasonable assurance of protection for personal information.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), 53(b), and 56(a); Section 621(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681s(a); Disposal Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 682; Safeguards Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314; Privacy Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 313

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit acknowledgments of receipt of the Order to the FTC and deliver copies of the Order to relevant personnel and entities, obtaining signed acknowledgments from recipients.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), 53(b), and 56(a); Section 621(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681s(a); Disposal Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 682; Safeguards Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314; Privacy Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 313

provisions.title: Annual Compliance Report
provisions.summary: Defendants must submit a comprehensive annual compliance report one year after entry of the Order, detailing contact information, business activities, and compliance with each section of the Order.

provisions.title: Compliance Notice for Changes
provisions.summary: Defendants must notify the FTC within 14 days of any changes to designated contact points or structural changes that may affect compliance obligations.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a), 53(b), and 56(a); Section 621(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681s(a); Disposal Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 682; Safeguards Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314; Privacy Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 313

provisions.title: Bankruptcy Notice
provisions.summary: Defendants must notify the FTC within 14 days of filing any bankruptcy petition, insolvency proceeding, or similar proceeding.

Part 682; Safeguards Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 314; Privacy Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 313

provisions.title: Recordkeeping Requirements
provisions.summary: Defendants must create and retain specified records for 20 years after Order entry, including accounting records, personnel records, complaints, compliance documentation, and marketing materials.

provisions.summary: The FTC and Plaintiff are authorized to monitor Defendants' compliance through document requests, depositions, interviews, and other discovery methods, including the ability to communicate directly with Defendants and pose as consumers.

provisions.title: GLB Rule Violations – Permanent Injunction
provisions.summary: Respondent and all persons acting in concert with it are permanently restrained from violating the Privacy Rule (16 C.F.R. Part 313 / 12 C.F.R. Part 1016) and the Safeguards Rule (16 C.F.R. Part 314).

provisions.title: Biennial Assessment Requirements

provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently enjoined from sending Unsolicited Commercial E-mail unless he first obtains a $1,000,000 performance bond, subject to specific terms regarding duration, surety, notice, and disclosure.

provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently enjoined from making any false or misleading express or implied misrepresentation or material omission in connection with Internet-advertised goods/services or residential mortgages, including mortgage terms, lender status, website security, and personal financial information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 108(c) of the Truth in Lending Act (TILA), 15 U.S.C. § 1607(c); and Sections 505(a)(7) and 522(a) of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act (GLB Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6805(a)(7) & 6822(a)

provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently enjoined from violating TILA and/or Regulation Z in connection with any advertisement promoting consumer credit extensions, including advertising inaccurate credit terms, rates, payment rates, or repayment periods.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 108(c) of the Truth in Lending Act (TILA), 15 U.S.C. § 1607(c); and Sections 505(a)(7) and 522(a) of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act (GLB Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6805(a)(7) & 6822(a)

provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently enjoined from violating or assisting others in violating Subtitle B of Title V of the GLB Act, including obtaining or attempting to obtain customer information of a financial institution through false, fictitious, or fraudulent statements.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 108(c) of the Truth in Lending Act (TILA), 15 U.S.C. § 1607(c); and Sections 505(a)(7) and 522(a) of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act (GLB Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6805(a)(7) & 6822(a)

provisions.summary: The FTC is authorized to monitor Defendant's compliance through written reports, document production, depositions, business inspections, discovery, undercover posing as consumers or suppliers, and interviews of personnel.
